suggestions.copy: This could be normal for <dog-name>. If so, continue to monitor <his-her-check> poop but be sure to look for any signs of discomfort, difficulty pooping or ill health and to notice if <he-she-check> is pooping less frequently than usual.

If this is unusual for <dog-name> or <he-she-check> seems unwell, uncomfortable while pooping or is not pooping everyday please ask <dog-name>’s vet for advice. Signs of ill health to look out for include: blood in their poop, loss of appetite tiredness.
Dogs are usually quite good at self-hydrating, but make sure <dog-name> always has plenty of fresh water available.

This could be normal for <dog-name>. Continue to monitor <his-her-check> poop and track <his-her-check> appetite and energy levels.
If this is unusual for <dog-name> or <he-she-check> seems unwell, consult <his-her-check> vet for advice.

If this is unusual for <dog-name> or <he-she-check> seems unwell, consult <his-her-check> vet for advice.
This could be normal for <dog-name>. Continue to monitor <his-her-check> poop and track <his-her-check> appetite and energy levels.
If this is unusual for <dog-name> or <he-she-check> seems unwell, consult <his-her-check> vet for advice.

You should closely monitor <dog-name>’s poops and if there are any signs of ill health e.g. vomiting or loss of appetite, or <he-she-check>’s pooping much more frequently than usual, contact <his-her-check> vet for advice.

If <dog-name>’s poops are always too wet, and/or <he-she-check>’s pooping more frequently than usual, you should consult <his-her-check> vet for advice, they may suggest changing <dog-name>’s diet or want to investigate a bit further.
Loose stools can lead to dehydration so make sure <dog-name> always has plenty of clean water available. Dietary changes can also help to improve your dog’s poop – ask your vet for advice.

Loose stools can lead to dehydration so make sure <dog-name> always has plenty of clean water available. Dietary changes can also help to improve your dog’s poop – ask your vet for advice.

You should closely monitor <dog-name>’s poops and if there are any signs of ill health e.g. vomiting or loss of appetite, or <he-she-check>’s pooping much more frequently than usual, contact <his-her-check> vet for advice.

If <dog-name>’s poops are always too wet, and/or <he-she-check>’s pooping more frequently than usual, you should consult <his-her-check> vet for advice, they may suggest changing <dog-name>’s diet or want to investigate a bit further.
Loose stools can lead to dehydration so make sure <dog-name> always has plenty of clean water available. Dietary changes can also help to improve your dog’s poop – ask your vet for advice.

Your dog’s poop is very soft or liquid. You should monitor <dog-name> closely. If this lasts more than 24 hours or if <dog-name> is unwell or has a high frequency of poops then consult <his-her-check> vet immediately. Signs of ill health to look out for include: vomiting, fever, blood in their poop, high frequency of poops, weight loss or loss of appetite.

If <dog-name>’s diarrhoea has persisted for more than 24 hours, or if you have seen other signs of ill health, then consult <his-her-check> vet immediately. Continue to track <dog-name>’s poops until your appointment. Recording more detail in the results section will help <his-her-check> vet with a diagnosis.

Diarrhoea can lead to dehydration so make sure <dog-name> always has plenty of clean, fresh water available (unless advised otherwise by your vet). Dietary changes can also help to improve your dog’s poop – ask your vet for advice.
